subject: Re: [junit]
msgSnippet: A little cleaner approach would be to set them in lists and have the tests iterate over the lists.  Each test method then iterates over the list of Components
messageBody:
A little cleaner approach would be to set them in lists and have the
tests iterate over the lists. Each test method then iterates over the
list of Components and performs its asserts/fails on each member of the
list. This list is most cleanly initialized in the abstract test's
setUp(). Of course that means that every time you execute a test, you
re-initialize the list of components (I would prefer that), but if you
don't want to do that use the TestSetup class.

There is really no need for embedding a class definition in the suite
method.

=jason

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002 17:17:43 +0400, "Kirill Maximov" <kir@...>
said:
> On 0, james.dobson@... wrote:
>
> I'm not quite sure that this will work, but it may:
>
> final TextComponent[] components = {
> new TextComponent(),
> new TextComponent("String")
> // more tested components
> };
>
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>
> for (int i = 0; i < components.length; i++)
> {
> AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest test =
> new AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest()
> {
> public TextComponent getTestedComponent()
> {
> return components[i];
> }
> }
> suite.addTestSuite(test.getClass());
> }
> return suite;
>
> Just a thought,
> KIR
>
> > That was my first thought as well, and the solution I currently have. But
> > consider this......
> >
> > You can instantiate a JTextField 5 different ways and a JTextArea 6. So
> > using the system that (I think) we agree is the way to go we would have to
> > subclass AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest 5 times for JTextField and 6 times
> > for JTextArea. And in each subclass instantiate the Text Area/Field
> > differently. E.g.
> >
> > // sub class one
> > new JTextArea()
> >
> > //sub class two
> > new JTextArea("Second Type Of Constructor")
> >
> > // etc
> >
> > However you look at it you have to extend AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest N
> > times, where N equals the possible number of constructors (for the different
> > objects) their are. I wanted to have N number of statements in one class
> > (the Test Client) rather than N number of very 'thin' subclasses. In the
> > end I don't suppose it matters, the behaviour would be the same.
> >
> > I suppose what I was after was, in pseudo code, was something like this:
> >
> > suite.addTestSuite(MyTestClass.class)
> > where component = new TextComponent()
> >
> > suite.addTestSuite(MyTestClass.class)
> > where component = new TextComponent("String")
> >
> > suite.addTestSuite(MyTestClass.class)
> > where component = new TextComponent(myDocument)
> >
> > etc etc etc
> >
> > Thanks for all the quick responses everyone.
> >
> > James
> >

> > Sorry,
> >
> > Misunderstood, probably RTFM (Reda The F***ing Mail) syndrome on my part.
> > What I think is the issue is that you should have an abstract test case
> > AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest that contains all testXxx() methods and an
> > instance variable of type JTextfield. Then make concrete subclasses
> > (ChildATest, ChildBTest,...), in the setUp you instantiate the correct one:
> >
> > public class ChildBTest extends AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest {
> > public void setUp(){
> > setMyTextfield(new ChildA());
> > }
> > }
> >
> > and then in the TestSuite:
> >
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >
> > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildATest.class));
> > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildBTest.class));
> > return suite;
> > }
> >
> > Even nicer would be to use a factory method in the concrete children.

> > > a class, but that class should contain some tests.
> > > In my situation I have a test MyTest that runs a number of
> > > tests against a
> > > JTextComponent. ChildA and ChildB are types of
> > > JTextComponent and do not
> > > contain any tests. I want to pass ChildA and ChildB to MyTest so that
> > > MyTest can test these different subclasses of JTextComponent.

> > >
> > > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildA.class));
> > > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildB.class));
> > > return suite;
> > > }

> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: james.dobson@... [mailto:james.dobson@...]

> > > >
> > > > Hi Everyone,
> > > >
> > > > Is it possible to automatically add all the tests of a test
> > > > class to a suite
> > > > without using 'suite.addTestSuite(MyTest.class)'?
> > > >
> > > > I have a test class that can test a number of classes from the same
> > > > hierarchy. Let's say for arguments sake that I have
> > > created two child
> > > > classes (ChildA and ChildB) of type JTextComponent and both
> > > > of them override
> > > > a number of methods such as setText. I have a number of
> > > > tests that test the
> > > > newly overridden methods. I have created a constructor for
> > > > the class that
> > > > looks something like this:
> > > >
> > > > public MyTest(String name, JTextComponent component)
> > > > {
> > > > super(name);
> > > > this.component = component;
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > My problem is this: I want to run this test twice, once for
> > > > childA and once
> > > > for childB. But I don't want to type in the tests individually e.g.
> > > >
> > > > public class MyTestClient
> > > > {
> > > > public static Test suite()
> > > > {
> > > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > > >
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > > ........
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > >
> > > > // Then the same for childB
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > ........
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > return suite;
> > > > }
> > > > public static void main(String[] args)
> > > > {
> > > > junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(MyTestClient.class);
> > > > }
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > How I would like to write the suite method is something like this:
> > > >
> > > > public static Test suite()
> > > > {
> > > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > > >
> > > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here
> > > > to indicate I
> > > > want to test ChildA */)
> > > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here
> > > > to indicate I
> > > > want to test ChildB */)
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > Hope this is a sensible question!
> > > >
